title: Data Sources
text: The major input data is NASA Team algorithm-derived SMMR-SSM/I-SSMIS sea ice concentration data over Antarctic Region (Cavalieri, 1996) for 36 years (October 1978 to December 2014). The data was downloaded from NSIDC data site: ( http://nsidc.org/data ).

title: Processing Steps
text: Following are the three major processing steps : i. Classification of pixels into sea-ice and non-sea-ice classes. ii. Determination of sea-ice-pixel frequency over study period iii. Calculation of Sea Ice Probability iv. Converting the data into three (.bin, .tif, and .png) formats.

title: Data Citation
text: Data Citation This dataset may be cited as (Rajak et al, 2015). Rajak D. Ram, R.K. Kamaljit Singh, Jayaprasad P., Sandip R. Oza, Rashmi Sharma, and Raj Kumar (2015). Sea Ice Occurrence Probability Data and Its Applications Over the Antarctic. Manuscript submitted to a journal. References

title: Derivation Techniques and Algorithm
text: Daily Probability of occurrence of sea ice: Pr = 100 x N / (Y-n) where, N, is the number of times the pixel has been classified as sea ice (sea ice concentration => 15%); Y, is the total possible observations, and n is the number of years with data loss on that particular date.

title: Limitations
text: Accuracy assessment of the dataset has not been carried out.

title: Known problems with data
text: The inherent problems of the major input sea ice concentration data (from NSIDC site) may be considered the problems with this dataset.

title: Related data collections
text: Northern Hemisphere EASE-Grid 2.0 Weekly Snow Cover and Sea Ice Extent. Version 4. Boulder, Colorado USA: NASA DAAC at the National Snow and Ice Data Center (Brodzik, M. and R. Armstrong. 2013.). [ http://nsidc.org/data ].

title: File Naming Convention
text: The file names follows SIOP36_MMDD_S.bin[.tif/.png] naming convention; Where MM refers to month number (01 to 12, 01 being January), DD refers to date of the month, and S refers to Southern Hemisphere. Data types are indicated by .bin (binary), .tif (geotiff), and .png (portable network graphics).
